action.action-desc: Mr. Grayson introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To allow the importation, distribution, and sale of investigational drugs and devices intended for use by terminally ill patients who execute an informed consent document.

section.header: Drugs and devices for use by terminally ill patients
section.text: The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended by inserting after section 561 (21 U.S.C. 360bbb) the following:

section.header: Drugs and devices for use by terminally ill patients

subsection.text: Nothing in this Act or section 351 of the Public Health Service Act prevents or restricts, and the Food and Drug Administration shall not implement or enforce any provision of law preventing or restricting, the importation, distribution, or sale of an investigational drug or device intended for use by a terminally ill patient in accordance with subsection (b).
In order for an investigational drug or device to be intended for use in accordance with this subsection, such drug or device must be intended for use by a patient who has—

paragraph.text: been diagnosed with a terminal illness by a licensed physician;
been informed by a licensed physician that no drug or device that is lawfully marketed in the United States is likely to cure the illness; and
executed a written informed consent document that states—

subparagraph.text: the known and potential risks and benefits of such drug or device; and
any indications of the illness for which a drug or device is lawfully marketed, or for which treatment is otherwise available, in the United States.

subsection.header: Definition of investigational drug or device
subsection.text: In this section, the term investigational drug or device means a drug or device that—

paragraph.text: has not yet been approved, licensed, or cleared for commercial distribution under section 505, 510(k), or 515 of this Act or section 351 of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 262), and cannot otherwise be lawfully marketed in the United States; and
is or has been the subject of one or more clinical trials.
